ch.aplu.turtle

Class Playground

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • javax.swing.JComponent
          • javax.swing.JPanel
            • ch.aplu.turtle.Playground
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.awt.print.Printable, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    TurtlePane

    public class Playground
extends javax.swing.JPanel
implements java.awt.print.Printable
    A Playground is the turtle's home, i.e. where the turtle moves and draws traces. ThePlayground is responsible for interpreting angle and position of the Turtle and for choosing the correct turtle image and putting it on the right spot of the Playground. This means: e.g. whenever you wish to switch the x- and y-axis, you should do it in this class, and not in the Turtle class. Remarks:
    • The Playground needs a Window (e.g. Frame, Applet) to be displayed. One possible solution for this problem is already given with the TurtleFrame class, which implements the TurtleContainer interface. Applets are not yet supported.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • Playground

        public Playground()
        Creates a Playground with standard size and default background color. The number of pixels is (401 x 401) and determines the span of turtle coordinates (-200..200)

      • Playground

        public Playground(java.awt.Color bkColor)
        Creates a Playground with standard size and given background color. The span of turtle coordinates is -200..200 and the window size in pixels is 401 x 401.

      • Playground

        public Playground(java.awt.Dimension size)
        Creates a new Playground with given size. size.width and size.height should be even positive integers. The size determines the span of turtle coordinates (-width/2 .. width/2, -height/2 .. height/2) and and the window size in pixels is (m+1) x (n+1).

      • Playground

        public Playground(java.awt.Dimension size,
          java.awt.Color bkColor)
        Creates a new Playground with given size and background color. size.width and size.height should be even positive integers. The size determines the span of turtle coordinates (-width/2 .. width/2, -height/2 .. height/2) and and the window size in pixels is (m+1) x (n+1).

    • Method Detail

      • getSize

        public java.awt.Dimension getSize()
        Returns the size (defines coordinate span) of the playground. If the playground size is m x n, the coordinate span in -m/2..m/2, -n/2..n/2 and the window size in pixels is (m+1) x (n+1).
        Overrides:
        getSize in class java.awt.Component

      • getBufferSize

        public java.awt.Dimension getBufferSize()
        Returns the size of the graphics buffer that holds the drawing area (number of pixels in horizontal direction and vertical direction). If the playground size is m x n, the coordinate span in -m/2..m/2, -n/2..n/2 and the buffer size is (m+1) x (n+1).

        public void paintTurtle(Turtle turtle)
        Paints the given Turtle.

      • drawImage

        public boolean drawImage(java.lang.String imagePath,
                double x,
                double y)
        Draws the given image into background. x,y is the center of the image in turtle coordinates. Retrieves the image either from the jar resource, from local drive or from a internet server From the given filename the image file is searched in the following order:
        - if application is packed into a jar archive, relative to the root of the jar archive
        - relative to the directory <userhome>/gamegrid/
        - relative or absolute to current application directory
        - if filename starts with http://, from the given URL
        - add prefix _ and search relative to the root of the jar archive
        Returns:
        true, if successful: otherwise false

      • drawImage

        public boolean drawImage(java.awt.image.BufferedImage bi,
                double x,
                double y)
        Draws the given buffered image into background. x,y is the center of the image in turtle coordinates.
        Returns:
        true, if successful: otherwise false

      • drawLine

        public void drawLine(double x0,
            double y0,
            double x1,
            double y1,
            Pen pen)
        Draws a line from the point (x0, y0) to (x1, y1) with the color and width of the given Pen.

      • fill

        public void fill(Turtle t)
        Fills a region with the Turtles fill color (flood fill). The region is defined by the Turtles actual position and is bounded by any other color than the pixel color at the turtle position. If this pixel color is the same as the fill color, nothing is done. If the current turtle position is outside the playground, nothing happens.

      • clear

        public void clear(java.awt.Color color)
        Clears the playground with given color. All traces are erased and all turtles are hidden, but remain where they are.

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Same as clear(Color color) with the current background color.

      • clean

        public void clean(java.awt.Color color)
        Cleans the traces using the given color. All turtles stay how and where they are, only lines, text and stamps will be removed.

      • clean

        public void clean()
        Same as clean(Color color) with the current background color.

      • setBkColor

        public void setBkColor(java.awt.Color color)
        Sets the background color of the playground. All turtle traces are erase, but the turtles remains where they are.

      • setBkImage

        public void setBkImage(java.lang.String imagePath)
        Draws the given image into the background (trace buffer). The image is loaded with Turtle.getImage(). If the image can't be loaded, nothing happens.
        Parameters:
        imagePath - the file name or url

      • paintComponent

        public void paintComponent()
        Paints the playground.

        public void clearTurtles()
        Remove all turtles from the turtle buffer.

      • clearTurtle

        public void clearTurtle(Turtle turtle)
        Removes the given turtle from the turtle buffer. Override this method if you have added a new behaviour (like wrap or clip) to the turtle.

         Turtle t)
        Same as label(String text, Turtle t, char align) with align = 'l'.

      • label

        public void label(java.lang.String text,
         Turtle t,
         char align)
        Draws the text at the current position of the Turtle t. Drawing a text at some coordinates (x,y) we mean that the bottom left corner of the text will be at these coordinates. Font and colour are specified by the Turtle's Pen. Text alignment: align = 'l' left, 'c': center, 'r': right

      • setAntiAliasing

        public void setAntiAliasing(boolean on)
        Sets antialiasing on or off for the turtle trace buffer This may result in an better trace quality.

      • print

        public int print(java.awt.Graphics g,

        int pageIndex)
        For internal use only. Implementation of Printable. (Callback method called by printing system.)
        Specified by:
        print in interface java.awt.print.Printable

      • getPixelColor

        public java.awt.Color getPixelColor(Turtle t)
        Returns the color of the pixel at the current turtle position. Returns null, if the turtle is outside the playground.

      • enableRepaint

        public void enableRepaint(boolean b)
        Enables/disables automatic screen rendering.

      • save

        public boolean save(java.lang.String fileName,
           java.lang.String formatName)
        Saves the playground (turtles and traces) in an image file.
        Parameters:
        fileName - the image file path
        formatName - the image format (supported values: "PNG", "GIF")
        Returns:
        true, if the operation is successful; otherwise false
